Definition: The "Percentage of Public Schools Using the Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction Modules in National Curriculum at All Levels" indicator measures the proportion of public schools that have integrated and are actively using climate change and disaster risk reduction (DRR) educational modules within the national curriculum across all grade levels. This indicator reflects the extent to which these critical topics are being taught in the education system.
Concept: This indicator tracks the adoption and implementation of educational content focused on climate change and disaster risk reduction within public schools. These modules are designed to educate students on the science of climate change, the importance of sustainability, and strategies to reduce disaster risks. By incorporating these topics into the national curriculum, the education system plays a crucial role in building a more informed and resilient future generation.
Rationale: Monitoring the percentage of public schools using climate change and DRR modules in the curriculum is essential for assessing the effectiveness of efforts to mainstream these topics into education. Teaching students about climate change and disaster risk reduction is key to raising awareness, fostering proactive attitudes, and equipping young people with the knowledge and skills needed to respond to and mitigate the impacts of environmental challenges.
MethodOfComputation:
To compute the "Percentage of Public Schools Using the Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction Modules in National Curriculum at All Levels," first identify all public schools that are part of the national education system. Assess whether these schools have integrated the climate change and disaster risk reduction modules into their curriculum across all levels of education. Calculate the percentage by dividing the number of schools using the modules by the total number of public schools, and multiply by 100 to express the result as a percentage.


Formula:
Percentage of Schools Using CC & DRR Modules (%) = (Number of Public Schools Using the Modules / Total Number of Public Schools) × 100
page_content: Vanuatu has developed a range of multi-hazard and risk maps to support Post-Disaster Needs Assessments (PDNAs) and strengthen disaster preparedness. These include national and provincial-level maps produced by the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) and localized risk maps developed by the National Advisory Board (NAB), covering hazards such as cyclones, floods, earthquakes, and volcanic activity. Over 50 hazard and risk maps have been produced for key areas like Port Vila and Luganville. These tools provide an evidence-based foundation for estimating disaster impacts and planning recovery efforts across multiple hazard types.
